text: Świetny balans pomiędzy kwaskowym profilem a owocowym aromatem. Genialnie ukryte alko i najlepszy balans. Czyli jak browar z USA wciągnął nosem wiele klasycznych Belgijskich flandersów ;)

Ooo taaak. Tego mi było trzeba. W aromacie morze czerwonych owoców, przede wszystkim wiśnia i malina. I wanilia. W smaku leciutkie, raczej wytrawne, wykwintne, wiśniowo - malinowe, kwaskowość ocierająca się o lekki ocet, perfekcyjny balans. Wanilia <3. Kocham.

Almanacs prestigious, upscaled (very) strong Flemish red, second edition, 2016 vintage bottle. A clear nod to Rodenbach Grand Cru, arguably the archetype in this old style - even the letters are suspiciously similar to those of Rodenbach, but this is an ambitious and complex elaboration on the theme of aged oud bruin, with added Californian Zinfandel grapes, raspberries and vanilla beans. From a luxurious 75 cl champagne bottle covered with an almost baroque motif and further provided with a classy hangtag with a Jack Kerouac quote on the backside - this whole thing looks chic and sophisticated, even a bit over-the-top in its ornamentation - and expensive. I think Im in for a treat today... Irregular, tightly cobweb-lacing, very moussy, even frothy, pale greyish white head, irregularly breaking in the middle but dense and stable on the edge, crowning a misty, beautifully vermillion-hued copper-bronze coloured beer, glowing in the sun, but turning completely clouded and more brownish burgundy with sediment, still very coppery though, like a jar of home-made quince jam. The nose reveals finesse, power and complexity upon opening the bottle, a whole array of well-matched impressions: first a whiff of elusive vanilla (from the vanilla beans), piercing through the nostrils but then shyly hiding in the background, immediately followed by somewhat more robust odours of tart raspberries and raspberry vinegar, even a cherry tomato-ish accent linked to them, soaking wet oak wood, rosé champagne, spicy and jammy Zinfandel wine indeed, redcurrant, oloroso, apple crumble, unsugared quince jam, maracuja, forest fruit yoghurt, sherry vinegar, yellow plums, some wry grape skin, soggy bread, krieken op jenever (gin-aged cherries), hints of violets, blueberries, damp earth (stronger with sediment, eventually even adding a very subtle urine-like aspect), Parfait dAmour, white rum, nectarine, rose petals. A ton of lush rosy and purple fruitiness instantly fills the mouth, both from the esters that befit a Flemish red and from the double added fruit dosis; I get a big wave of red raspberries as well as - a couple of seconds later and a bit deeper - sweet and spicy Zinfandel grapes, mixing well with each other and with the esters, the latter of which add impressions of ripe nectarine, red apple, redcurrant and a dash of pomegranate. The generously sweet fruit flavours are embedded in a beautiful tartness, drying and elegantly sour without becoming too acidic, with a hint of fruit peel wryness; mouthfeel is just perfect, smooth and soft, with finely tingling, lambrusco-like carbonation which only enhances the flavours rather than covering them up. The fruit wave travels onwards over a lovely bready and even very lightly caramelly malt sweetish basis, while the overall tartness keeps it dry and extremely appetizing; the finish accentuates this dryness with elegant wood tannins, releasing vanilla-ish notes - and this is where the added vanilla beans make their contribution, in subtly working together with the much more dim vanilla-ish properties of the oak, volatile and gracious; the wood never becomes overly expressive, as would be the case in the finest of authentic Flemish reds (think Rodenbach Vintage, for example). At 10+% ABV, it comes as no surprise that a late glow of soft, sherry-like alcohol joins in at the very end, mingling with the ongoing fruit tartness, fruit juiciness, soft tannic woodiness and malt sweetishness. The fruit tartness lasts the longest after swallowing. My, this is a thing of sheer beauty... I was expecting something worthwile (also given the price and the other beers I had from this brewery), but this exceeds my expectations. This may well be the best oud bruin I ever had - including the original Flemish examples, and I hate to admit this. It understands the essence of this difficult and complicated, (now) highly revered style much better than almost any other non-Flemish oud bruin I had so far; the craft beer movement is all about experimenting with existing beer styles, reviving old styles that were all but forgotten, mixing them into hybrids and creating new ones so it is no wonder that so many of these new generation brewers throughout the world want to tackle this ancient - and originally relatively humble - European sour beer style, especially given the sour craze that has been going on in recent years, but many of them get stuck in sourness too much, forgetting about the soft, bready, moelleux maltiness this style needs to truly shine. This ones does it completely right, and adds further complexity with grapes, raspberries and vanilla in a well-thought and well-balanced manner. An absolute must for whoever likes this original sour ale style. I had no idea Almanac was capable of this degree of awesomeness... Justly a top-50 oud bruin here.
Thanks Carl! Lovely red color with pinkish head. Very earthy and fruity red sour. Big dark fruit, oak, vanilla, red wine, and tobacco.
Red hazy with minimal white head. Sour fruity aroma. Sour fruity taste with some bitterness on the background. Lasting fruity sour aftertaste.
Restrained tart aroma in a cherry pour. Big tart taste to match with a subtle hint of berry and vanilla making for a deliciously complex drink. The best of the Almanac sours (to my taste at least).

750ml bottle. Pours deep red. Raspberry, cherry, blueberry, sweet vanilla, lemon, balsamic vinegar, thyme, custard, blackcurrant, blackberry. Beautiful fizzy body. An outrageous combination of complexity and beautiful clean flavours. The grapes, raspberry and vanilla all get to sing but the beer is so much more than the sum of those parts. Just sublime.
750ml Bottle. Pours a murky red with white head. Red fruit nose. Very tart with strong red wine notes, and hidden vanilla flavours in the background.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2017 Sour, musty nose with a hint of raspberry. Murky rust color with no head. Tight, mouth puckering sour like a balsamic, notes of cherries. Thin body but well balanced. goes down easy - way to easy! good.

4/2/17. 750mL bottle thanks to Carl. Red pour with a small pink head. Good aroma, sour, tart, funky, leather and tobacco, berries, vanilla definitely there, some wine and oak. Good flavor, sour, tobacco and leather, earthy, berries, vanilla, oak. Tasty!
750ml bottle. Poured a ruby color with a smaller sized head. Berries, vanilla comes through as it warms, tart fruits, wood, and some red wine. Medium tart finish with the alcohol well hidden.

Shared 2016, 750 ml. bottle poured to snifters displaying a hazed, rosy color, with a bubbly layer of pinkish white foam, and spots of lacing. The nose was fruity with raspberry & grape, light funk, oak, and tartness that is mellowed slightly by vanilla. Medium bodied, with complementary carbonation, the taste was similar notes, sour & dry, in a pleasantly non-puckering way.

[1/25/17] Draught at Almanac Taproom in San Francisco. Cloudy red-amber. Aroma of wine, grapes, berries, oak, vanilla. Sour flavor with oak, lacto, berries, wine, some vanilla, vinegar, somewhat acidic. Medium-bodied. Very good, just a bit too acidic.

Pours foggy rosehip with minimal head 
Aromas tart of sour cherries, oak, burned caramel , spices
Taste has tart notes of sour cherries, red grapes, red fruits

Pours hazy blood orange with a low white head. Aromas of red currant, red apples, citrus, minerals, cherries. Taste is very fruity and quite sour with oak notes. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation an quite dry.

Tap at SF Beer Week Opening Gala.

Pours cloudy light brown.
Aroma is oak, wine grapes, Brett.
Medium body, super sour, a little sweeter than the white, fruity too.
Long sour palate. Good.

Oaky woody dark fruit aroma with nice lactic finish. Sour is maybe 5 of 10 sour, all lactic. Great dark fruit complexity, cherry, fig dark fruit woody complexities. Has less body than I expected for a stronger sour, and a bit of an almost syrupy cherry sweetness to the finish. Those are minor though, it is complex and balanced and flavorful. Alcohol is masked very well. Cherry woody sour is the dominant flavor. Really nice. Was expecting a world class beer like consecration and it is a notch below. Great sour, but not world class. Has a rose wine like feel to it due to high alcohol and lighter body. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle. Tart raspberry aroma with notes of grape, red wine and vanilla. Pours dark red colored with a nearly nonexistent white head that has no retention or lacing. Starts with sweet/tart raspberry flavor with grape and vanilla notes. Finishes dry and quite tart with excellent vinous red wine flavor and mouthfeel that lingers on the palate like a dry red wine. Excellent sour!

On [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ red opaque with tan off-white head. Aroma: raspberries, hint of vanilla, which is perfectly integrated, grapes, hint of best vinegar, vanillin, oak, wine...taninns, slightly astringent, dry finish, medium body & carbonation, silky texture. Masterpiece!!*

Pours a deep brownish red hue with little to no head. Sour cherries on the nose. Deep sourness with brown sugar, luxardo cherry, and wheat notes throughout. Thick and sticky with medium low carbonation. Excellent brew

Cloudy reddish color, moderate sized white head that lasts given the alcohol. Aroma of barnyard action, brett, raspberry, yeast, vinegar, cherry. Medium bodied, moderate to high tartness, moderately sweet as well to balance. Alcohol hidden well. This is a really nice sour, American or not.

Bottle. Pours lightly hazy reddish amber, small kinda fizzy off-white head, dissipates fairly quickly with decent residual and lacing. Aroma is full of berries, raspberry for sure, lactic sour, oak tannin, vinous notes. Flavor is medium tart, hints of nice funk, berry seeds and stems, raspberry flesh, vinous. Not really getting vanilla per se, but I am sure it is adding to overall complexity, which is high. Medium body, low carbonation but a soft mouthfeel. This is a truly excellent Sour Red and deserves some serious accolades.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 9/29/2016. Pours fairly hazy/cloudy reddish orange color with a 1 finger dense light pink head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big tart/sour cherry, raspberry, strawberry, lemon, green apple, plum, red grape, almond, vanilla, toasted oak, hay, straw, pepper, and bread; with lighter notes of leather, red wine vinegar, funk, and yeast/oak earthiness. Incredible aromas with fantastic complexity and balance of fruity/spicy/acidic yeast, fruit/vanilla, oak barrel, and moderate bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of huge tart/sour cherry, raspberry, strawberry, lemon, green apple, plum, red grape, almond, vanilla, toasted oak, hay, straw, pepper, and bread; with lighter notes of leather, red wine vinegar, funk, and yeast/oak earthiness. Moderate fruity/lactic tart/sourness and yeast/tannic oak spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of sour cherry, raspberry, strawberry, lemon, green apple, plum, red grape, almond, vanilla, toasted oak, hay, straw, pepper, bread, light leather/red wine vinegar, and yeast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy/acidic yeast, fruit/vanilla, oak barrel, and moderate bready malt flavors; with a great malt/tannic/sourness balance, and zero puckering/astringent flavors after the finish. Moderate dryness for acidity/tannins, increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and acidic/tannic/grainy balanced mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 10.5%. Overall this is an incredible fruited sour ale! All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy/acidic yeast, fruit/vanilla, oak barrel, and moderate bready malt flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to sip on, thanks to the balanced acidity and wine/oak tannins. A highly enjoyable offering.
Bottle: Fruit punch look with AMAZING flavors of berries and tart apples on the finish. An absolute treat!

750 mL bottle from The Hop Yard, Raleigh. Pour that appears pink from the bottle but looks red in the glass. Tart aroma of raspberry and red grape with faint damp oak. Taste is sour, one of the most sour beers I have ever tasted, with loads of red fruit and zinfandel with faint oak and vanilla. Tartness lingers on the palate. A great sour!
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours near red with a foamy pinkish head and a marvelous raspberry aroma. There is an intense fruit flavor, mostly raspberry and grape. Dry musty oaky grape finish.

Capped 750 from Corti Bros. Pours a dark pink/rose with a slight, transient head. Aroma is spot on sour red/brown. Med body. Flavor is fruit, sour, wood/oak. And lots of raspberry. It is dry and astringent. Quite nice. Excellent even.

Draught at the 20th Pizza Port Strong Ale Festival. Pours ruby with a medium, frothy off-white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is acetic cherries with cracker and biscuit malt, light spices. Flavor is acetic cherries with bready malt, spices and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

From a bottle. Strawberry rhubarb color. Berries, oak, and some vanilla on the nose. Flavor has a wonderful balance, building tartness steadily, emphasizing barrel character and adding a lovely dusty note. Lots of strawberry, though I dont think thats in there. Really tasty stuff.
